comments:
I'm following the steps on setting up the COSMOS data collector environment.  When I run the debug launch configuration, I get the following output:

org.apache.muse.ws.addressing.soap.SoapFault: Connection refused: connect
	at org.apache.muse.core.AbstractResourceClient.invoke(AbstractResourceClient.java:298)

	at org.eclipse.equinox.ds.instance.InstanceProcess.registerComponentConfigurations(InstanceProcess.java:145)

	at org.eclipse.equinox.ds.workqueue.WorkQueue$Queued.dispatch(WorkQueue.java:57)
	at org.eclipse.equinox.ds.workqueue.WorkQueue.run(WorkQueue.java:108)

The NPE actually appears multiple times, but I just pasted it once since it's the same text each time.

My command line args and the # of bundles selected in the launch configuration seem to match Hubert's setup.  Is there possibly something else I need to configure or setup that I'm missing?  Even if I have a setup problem, it would seem that a null check would be good to deliver a better message than an NPE.

This can be caused by a port conflict. From the stack trace, it appears that the initial soap request is failing due to a refused connection. It might be helpful to verify that an osgi http service is running in this configuration and that it is listening on it's designated port.

(In reply to comment #1)
> This can be caused by a port conflict. From the stack trace, it appears that
> the initial soap request is failing due to a refused connection. It might be
> helpful to verify that an osgi http service is running in this configuration
> and that it is listening on it's designated port. 

Here were the messages that immediately preceded the stack trace:

Jun 27, 2007 10:49:17 AM org.mortbay.util.ThreadedServer start
WARNING: Failed to start: SocketListener0@0.0.0.0:8080
Pinging Muse to initialize the endpoint...

How do I do the verification you suggested?

I am assuming the code change made it into the current candidate build.  I installed the build and changed the port number in the VM arguments to 80.

I am definitely getting different results now, though it still seems like it isn't working properly, like it should be doing an absolute file path where it's treating it as a relative path.  Will it still run even if it can't write to the muse log?

I'm in the section:

Viewing reports from Sample database and Data Center SML

   1. Start Tomcat server by running <server_home>\bin\startup.bat
   2. Open IE 6.0 or Mozilla Firefox 1.5 browser and point to http://localhost:8080/COSMOSUI/index.jsp?view=cosmos.

How do I indicate a port other than 8080?  I already have something else on 8080.  I didn't see any cmd line args for this in the Tomcat .bat file

Well, I did find a config file in Tomcat where I could change the port #, but it must not have been the only place to do it, since I still got a conflict later on for 8080.  So I have basically turned off the other process I had running on 8080 so I can just get this up and running.

The suppression of the NPE stack traces will be tracked under bug #196704

The suppression of the soap fault stack traces will be tracked under bug #196712

The primary issue of resolving Tomcat port conflicts is beyond the scope of the current demo.  The demo has been confirmed to work properly when Tomcat is functioning properly.
